chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The XSLT plugin provides features for transforming XML documents using XSLT stylesheets, saving transformation configuration settings and viewing the results of evaluating XPath expressions.
NOTE: The XML indent functionality that formerly was included in the XSLT plugin has been moved into the XML plugin.

chapter.title: XSLT Processor Tool
chapter.para: The XSLT Processor allows you to transform a source XML document using a series of XSL stylesheets. XSL and XSLT are W3C-specified standards for XML stylesheets and stylesheet transformations, respectively.

To use the XSLT Processor:
To dock the tool, from the Plugins menu select "XSLT->XSLT Processor". Note that you may select where a Plugin is docked from "Utilies->Global Options->jEdit->Docking".
Select a source XML file, by using the "Select XML source" button and subsequent dialog. The button is located next to the source text field at the top of the tool.
Modify the list of stylesheets using the buttons with the "Add stylesheet", "Remove stylesheet", "Move up" and "Move down" buttons (the buttons with the plus, minus, up and down icons).
If the first stylesheet in the list has parameters that you wish to populate, you can add parameters via the "Add stylesheet parameter" button. For example if the XSLT param element is <xsl:param name="uri"/>, you can add a parameter with name "uri" to the parameter table.
Name a file for the result to be saved to by pressing the "Name result file" button next to the result text field at the bottom of the tool. In the dialog window select a directory, enter a file name and then press the "Open" button (a bit confusing but it will work).
The result will be written to a new untitled buffer if you click the New Untitled Buffer radio button. Note that it will be written in memory only, so don't use this option with too big a document. Also note that if any <xsl:result-document> instruction is used, it won't be written in memory but to a file relative to the new Untitled buffer.
Files can be opened for editing from the XSLT Processor window, using enter key, or right click menu select on the file name.
If you don't want to open the result of the transformation (e.g. because the result is too big), uncheck the Open result check-box.
Run the transformation using the "Transform XML" button. This will perform the selected XSL transformations on the source XML and place the result in a new buffer. If more than one stylesheet is selected then the result from a prior stylesheet in the list becomes the input to the next stylesheet. If you entered a result file name, then the new buffer will be saved to a file with that name.
You can invoke the "Transform XML" action via a keyboard shortcut or toolbar icon; this can be configured from "Utilities->Global Options->jEdit->Shortcuts" or "Utilities->Global Options->jEdit->Tool Bar" respectively. The XSLT Processor will have to be docked in order for this binding to work.
You can save the current settings by clicking on the "Save settings" button, which is next to the "Transform XML button". In the File System Browser dialog specify a name for the settings file, then click "Save". The saved settings are formatted as an Ant build file. This build file can be run with Ant independently of the plugin to perform the same transformation. If you want to make manual changes to this file and still be able to load the original settings, keep a copy of the original file. To run Ant files from within jEdit, download the "Ant Farm" plugin.
Saved settings can be loaded via the "Load saved settings" button, which is next to the "Save settings" button. In the File System Browser dialog select the settings file that you wish to load, then click "Open". The settings from file will be loaded into the GUI. Caution, if you have manually changed the settings file, it may no longer be loadable by the XSLT plugin.

section.title: Error Reporting
section.para: Errors are reported via the ErrorList plugin and/or a popup message :

listitem.para: any error due to a broken stylesheet will result in an error in the ErrorList dockable and a popup dialog telling you about the error;
any error while reading the source document will result in an error in the ErrorList dockable and a popup dialog telling you about the error;

any warning reported by the XSLT processor will only be reported as a warning in the ErrorList dockable. Be warned that some pretty strong errors (like an xsl:element with an invalid name, thus not created) are not reported;
any error (error or fatalError) reported by the XSLT processor will be reported in the ErrorList dockable and in a popup dialog.

section.para: Processing will be immediately terminated in case of error (even non-fatal), but will continue in case of warnings.

section.title: To Do...
section.para:
The following improvements should eventually be made to XSLT Processor.
Users should be able to edit the XSLT Processor settings (e.g. indent amount) via an XSLT plugin section in global options. Note: The indent amount for the result XML is set to 2 spaces per indent level. Currently this setting can only be changed in the XSLT.props file, which is contained in the XSLT.jar file.

section.title: Compiling a stylesheet
section.para: I find it useful to have the stylesheet compiled even if don't run the stylesheet in jEdit. This allows for basic tests to be performed on the stylesheet and catches many stupid errors that I would only have seen when running it. I found the Saxon 9.2 XSLT processor to report the most errors; this may be related to the precisions in the XSLT 2.0 specification, but I heard that Michael Kay put a good deal of effort in outputting explicit error messages.
Anyway, you can invoke the action xslt.compile to compile the stylesheet in current buffer.You can also check an option in the XSLT option pane (see ) to always compile XSLT stylesheets on save.

section.title: Three-way mode
section.para: The three-way mode is intended to provide a comfortable workbench for experimenting with XSLT.

To activate this mode, you can use the menu Plugins > XSLT > 3-Way mode, or the action xslt.three-way-mode. This will split the current view in three, open three buffers and insert a template stylesheet in the second one (version 1.0 or 2.0, depending upon the XSLT processor you selected in the Plugin Options). It will also open the XSLT processor dockable, (which I usually dock at left) and enable its 3-way mode.

As long as an xml buffer and an xslt buffer can be found, the buffers can be in any order. However, if the edit modes don't match exactly, the buffers will used in the order listed above, regardless of their mode. If 2 buffers are in xml mode, the first one will be assumed to be the source. If 2 buffers are in xsl mode, the canonical ordering will be used.

The result of the transformation will be inserted in the result buffer if the result buffer is not read-only, or in a new untitled buffer otherwise. Any previous content of the result buffer will be available via the Undo action.

note.para: This feature is still experimental; feedback on its usability would be appreciated.

chapter.title: XPath Tool
chapter.para: The XPath Tool allows you to evaluate XPath expressions on XML in the current buffer. XPath is a W3C-specified expression language used to access or refer to parts of an XML document. Depending on the XPath engine you choose, you can also use XPath 2.0.

To use the XPath Tool:
Open a file containing well-formed XML.
From the Plugins menu, select "XSLT->XPath Tool" to dock the tool.
Enter your XPath expression into the upper text area labeled "XPath Expression". You can navigate a history of recently executed XPath expressions in the XPath expression text area using the page up and page down keys.
If your XPath expression uses namespace qualified names, you may have to add namespace bindings in the Namespace Context table. You may bind the same namespace to multiple prefixes, but one prefix may only refer to one namespace.
To grab the namespaces used in the source document, click on the button next to Evaluate XPath in the middle of the XPath tool dockable.
Use the "Evaluate XPath" button, to evalute the the expression against the current buffer. The result information displayed includes:
the result data type;
if the result type is not node-set, the result value;
if the result type is node-set, the node-set string value, a table summary of the nodes in the set and the nodes displayed as XML fragments.
You can invoke the "Evalute XPath" action via a keyboard shortcut or toolbar icon; this can be configured from "Utilities->Global Options->jEdit->Shortcuts" or "Utilities->Global Options->jEdit->Tool Bar" respectively. The XPath Tool will have to be docked in order for this binding to work.

The following improvements should eventually be made to XPath Tool.
When the result of an evaluation is a Node set, it would be nice to have a "Hyper Search" type of result. In other words, each node in the list could be clicked to highlight the relevant portion of the XML doc in the current buffer.

section.title: Extending the XPath tool
section.para: The XPath engine is not as configurable as the XSLT processor, since the java XPath API (javax.xml.xpath.*) doesn't provide enough services for the XPath tool. So I had to tap into the native APIs of each engine.
If you want to use another XPath engine, you have to implement xslt.XPathAdapter, package it as a jar, drop it in "JEDIT_SETTINGS"/jars and set the xpath.adapter property to the name of your class.

chapter.title: XSLT Plugin option pane
chapter.para: You can choose which XSLT processor to use by selecting one option in the combo-box in the Plugins / XSLT section of the Plugins > Plugin Options dialog.

listitem.para: you can also use the 6.5.5 version of the SAXON XSLT Processor from Michael Kay. This version of Saxon is XSLT 1.0 compliant.

You may obtain Saxon 6.5.5 from Sourceforge (https://sourceforge.net/projects/saxon/files/) or from Saxonica (http://www.saxonica.com). It is released under the Mozilla Public License Version 1.0 or under a commercial license (again, see http://www.saxonica.com).
Last but not least, you can use version 9.x of the SAXON XSLT Processor from Michael Kay, which is an XSLT 2.0 processor.
It is packaged for jEdit as the SaxonPlugin. Once you have installed it via the Plugin Manager, simply choose it in the XSLT processor combo box.

chapter.para: To use a processor which is not distributed with the plugin, simply drop the jar files in the jars directory within the settings directory (which you can browse via the Utilities > Settings Directory). You will then have to enter the class name of its implementation of javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory. After a restart of jEdit, you will be using the selected XSLT processor.
You can also choose an XPath engine to use by selecting one option in the XPath engine combo-box in the Plugins / XSLT section of the Plugins > Plugin Options dialog.

listitem.para: for XPath 1.0, use the Xalan engine;
for XPath 2.0, use the Saxon 9 engine;
to use another engine, see ;

chapter.para: You can also choose to run a compilation of the stylesheets on save (see ). I find it helpful to perform some checks on the stylesheet.

Unified the XSLT and XPath input options.
When the result file input contains an invalid file (e.g. blank), the result will be written to a nameless buffer that can be saved under a name of choice.
Changed XSLT panel horizontal layout for top and bottom docking.
0.5.1 requires >=jEdit 4.1 and >=XML plugin 0.11
Known issue: cannot perform transformations running under JDK 1.4.* on Windows after normal plugin install.
The XML indent functionality that formerly was included in the XSLT plugin has been moved into the separate XML Indenter plugin.
A history of recent executed XPath expressions can be navigated in the XPath expression text area using page up and page down keys.
Can open files for editing from the XSLT Processor window, using enter key, or double click, or right click menu select on file name.

Transformation result is written directly to file. The file is opened in a new buffer, or the file is reloaded if already open in a buffer. If the file is already open then the result buffer will not gain focus after transformation is completed, this is helpful for when using split panes while editing. Perhaps whether the result buffer gets the focus should be made configurable in a future release.
Cleaned up XSLT.props file and simplified property names. A consequence of this change is that key shortcuts for the plugin will have to be configured again for previous users.

Enforce user definition of source, stylesheet and result settings. If a setting is missing it is neither possible to run transformation nor save settings to file. A dialog will tell the user what setting is missing.
Fixed bug running XPath on files containing CDATA.
Fixed bug that happened when running transformation with no stylesheet parameters defined.
Stylesheet settings can now be saved and loaded. The settings are saved to file in an Ant build format. These files can be run with Ant independently of the XSLT plugin.
Stylesheet parameters now definable at the GUI.
Improved DTD handling, now uses same entity resolution mechanism as the XML plugin.
Fixed bug running XPath on remote files.
Fixed transformation bug due to missing property in the XSLT.props file.
Fixed some indent problems related to handling tab characters.

Indent XML feature now uses the buffer options to determine the indent amount and whether to indent using tabs. Indent action is now performed as a compound edit, therefore only requiring one undo command to undo.

Improved display of XPath expression results, including result data type, result value or node-set string value, and for node-set results a table summary of nodes in the set and the nodes displayed as XML fragments.
New implementation of Indent XML feature that does not replace entity values in the XML.
Fix for problems displaying new lines characters under Windows.
New "4.1" theme icons on buttons.
Improved XSLT functionality, including facility to auto-save result buffer to a named file, and an Indent XML Buffer action.
